content.text: Measure the length \(l\), width \(w\) and height \(h\) of the sample A of modelling clay. Do **not** change the shape of the sample
Calculate the volume \(V_{\mathrm{A}}\) of sample A using the equation \(V_{\mathrm{A}} = l\times w\times h\)
Measure and record the mass \(m_{\mathrm{A}}\) of sample A of modelling clay using the balance provided
Calculate the density \(\rho_{\mathrm{A}}\) of sample A using the equation \(\rho_{\mathrm{A}} = \frac{m_{\mathrm{A}}}{V_{\mathrm{A}}}\)
Give your answer to a suitable number of significant figures for this method and include the unit
\(\rho_{\mathrm{A}} =\)
Method 2
Record the volume \(V_{1}\) of water in the measuring cylinder
Carefully lower sample B of the same modelling clay into the measuring cylinder until it is completely covered with water
Record the new reading \(V_{2}\) of the water level in the measuring cylinder
Calculate the volume \(V_{\mathrm{B}}\) of sample B using the equation \(V_{\mathrm{B}} = V_{2} - V_{1}\)
Measure and record the mass \(m_{\mathrm{B}}\) of sample B of measuring clay using the balance provided
\(m_{\mathrm{B}} =\)
Calculate the density \(\rho_{\mathrm{B}}\) of sample B using the equation \(\rho_{\mathrm{B}} = \frac{m_{\mathrm{B}}}{V_{\mathrm{B}}}\)
Give your answer to a suitable number of significant figures for this experiment and include the unit
\(\rho_{\mathrm{B}} =\)
Pour approximately \(50 \text{cm}^3\) of the water provided into the measuring cylinder
A student suggests that the density of modelling clay is not affected by either the mass or the volume of the sample used
State whether your results agree with the suggestion. Justify your answer by reference to your results
statement
justification
Fig. 1.1 shows some water in a measuring cylinder. The surface of the liquid is curved and is called the meniscus
Tick the boxes that describe the correct line of sight for taking a reading of the volume of water in a measuring cylinder
along the scale
parallel to the scale
perpendicular to the scale
vertical to the scale
in line with the bottom of the meniscus
in line with the top of the meniscus
in line with midway between the top and bottom of the meniscus
In this experiment, you will determine the density of modelling clay by two methods
**Method 1**
Use the thermometer to measure room temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\)
Pour \(200 \text{cm}^3\) of hot water into the beaker. Place the thermometer in the beaker by moving the clamp stand
Record in Table 2.1 the temperature \(\theta_{1}\) of the hot water at time \(t = 0\). Immediately start the stopclock
After 180 s, measure the temperature \(\theta_{1}\) of the water. Record the time \(t = 180 \text{s}\) and the temperature reading in Table 2.1
Calculate the drop in temperature \(\Delta \theta_{1}\) between times \(t = 0\) and \(t = 180 \text{s}\)
Calculate the average rate of cooling \(R_{1}\) of the water using the equation \(R_{1} = \frac{\Delta \theta_{1}}{\Delta t}\) , where \(\Delta t = 180 \text{s}\). Include the unit
Empty the beaker
Pour \(150 \text{cm}^3\) of hot water into the beaker. Add \(50 \text{cm}^3\) of cold water to the beaker. Place the thermometer in the beaker by moving the clamp stand
Record in Table 2.2 the temperature \(\theta_2\) of the water in the beaker at time \(t = 0\). Immediately start the stopclock
After \(180 \text{s}\), measure the temperature \(\theta_2\) of the water. Record the time \(t = 180 \text{s}\) and the temperature reading in Table 2.2
Calculate the drop in temperature \(\Delta \theta_2\) between \(t = 0\) and \(t = 180 \text{s}\)
Calculate the average rate of cooling \(R_2\) of the water using the equation \(R_2 = \frac{\Delta \theta_2}{\Delta t}\), where \(\Delta t = 180 \text{s}\). Include the unit
Calculate the difference \(D_{1}\) using the readings in Table 2.1 and your answer to (a)
Calculate the difference \(D_{2}\) using the readings in Table 2.2 and your answer to (a)
Write a conclusion about the relationship between \(R\) and \(D\). Justify your answer by reference to your results
conclusion
justification
A student suggests that the average rate of cooling \(R\) of the water depends on the difference \(D\) between the temperature of the water at time \(t = 0\) and room temperature
Explain why the thermometer scale should be read at right angles
Explain why the mixture of hot and cold water should be stirred before taking the temperature reading at the start of the experiment in (c)(i)
In this experiment, you will investigate the cooling of water under different conditions
Carry out the following instructions referring to Fig. 2.1. The thermometer must remain in the clamp for the whole of this experiment. Do **not** adjust the position of the thermometer in the clamp
Measure and record the height \(h_{\mathrm{O}}\) of the illuminated object provided in your experiment
Place the lens a distance \(u = 20.0 \text{cm}\) from the illuminated object
Move the screen slowly until a clearly-focused image is formed on the screen
Measure the distance \(\nu\) between the centre of the lens and the screen and record the value in Table 3.1
Calculate, and record in Table 3.1, the magnification \(m\) using the equation \(m = \frac{\nu}{u}\)
Repeat the procedure using values of \(u\) equal to 25.0 cm, 30.0 cm, 35.0 cm and 40.0 cm
Plot a graph of \(u / \text{cm}\) (y-axis) against \(m\) (x-axis). Start the \(y\)-axis at \(u = 20.0 \text{cm}\)
Use the graph to determine the value of the object distance \(u_{1}\) when the magnification \(m = 1.0\)
Show clearly on the graph how you obtained the necessary information
Calculate the focal length \(f\) of the lens using the equation \(f = \frac{u_{1}}{2}\)
In this experiment, you will investigate the magnification of the image produced by a lens
Carry out the following instructions referring to Fig. 3.1 and Fig. 3.2
Fig. 3.2 This figure has **not** been drawn to scale
A student investigates the resistances of different wires
Plan an experiment to investigate the resistances of wires made from different metals
Resistance is calculated using the equation \(R = \frac{V}{I}\). You are **not** required to carry out the investigation
The following apparatus is available:
ammeter
voltmeter
power supply
metre rule
a selection of wires made from different metals
You can also use other apparatus and materials that are usually available in a school laboratory
In your plan, you should:
write a list of suitable metals for the wires you will investigate
draw a diagram of a suitable electrical circuit using standard electrical symbols
explain briefly how to carry out the investigation
state the key variables to keep constant
draw a table, or tables, with column headings, to show how to display your readings (you are **not** required to enter any readings in the table)
